nodes.bodyText: PinotBrokerPageSourceSQL ?
will do
I am wondering if this file is same as PinotBrokerPageSource.java ? I kind of skipped reviewing it in detail :-)
mostly, just abstract it :)

The whole notion of expected column handles comes from the fact that the PQL end point returns the group by results first before the aggregations. (and that it fails with not having aggregations and thus we have to introduce fake aggregations).
I am wondering if this constraint also holds for the SQL end point ? if not, then I think we should push this method to be abstract here.

Let me double check on that.
From sql endpoint, we removed the constraint, so expectedColumnHandles should be same as columnHandles
move expectedColumnHandles to PinotBrokerPageSourcePql
Take a look at the comment below: expectedHandles may not even belong here.
moved
Comments around the abstract methods to signify their purpose ?
will do
Error message should state that resultTable is missing.
will do
How about a better name for 'body' ?
renamed to responseJsonString
Should we check state that exactly one of 'sql' or 'pql' is set ?
will do
added the check for exact one query to be set.
Didn't read this too carefully ... this looks like a giant copy paste :-). What's the main change from PQL generation ?

Current major diff is to change TOP to LIMIT.
Here I expect the future change will happen more on SQL side than PQL side, so intentionally to separate both.
I will abstract common parts(selection/filtering) to until functions for now.

extract the common logic to a method.
Currently SELECT/LIMIT clauses are generated differently.

How should the segment code path change ? I am not sure if the Pinot Servers also understand "SQL" (vs PQL) ? For that matter, I have forgotten whether the Presto Worker does the PQL to Pinot Plan conversion and sends that to the Pinot Servers or how that translation works (perhaps in the Pinot Driver jar).
We may want to double check that and then perhaps disable SQL for the segment code path.
Pinot Server query only do select columns from a table. Server query is still the same.
How about renaming this to generatePinotQueryHelper or generatePinotQueryCommon or such to make it clear that this is just a helper function.
Just double checking: In PQL generation we omit the group by columns from the "select expressions". I am assuming that is NOT done in the SQL generation ?

Yes.
PQL omit groupby columns
SQL will return whatever shows in selection expression.
e.g. SELECT count(*) FROM myTable GROUP BY col; will still just return counts without group by col.

I can only see tests that are deleted here (that perhaps don't belong in the SQL codepath). I don't see any new tests added here.
I am wondering if it makes sense to actually test out the SQL query generation logic ? Things like using orderby-over-aggregation works, 'limit with aggregation", "group by expressions in select clause" and such.
I think this is still a concern ?

Yes, I will add more tests related to sql.
orderby-over-aggregation-groupby-limit.
I think aggregation doesn't need to support limit?
This is not so much about just the SQL syntax, is it ? Its also about using the SQL endpoint instead of the PQL endpoint.

nodes.bodyText: This may be a nitpick, so feel free to ignore it: Should we just have a 'final String query' field here along with a 'final PinotQueryFormat queryFormat', instead of having these two strings and then checking that only one of them is set ?
I'm actually thinking of the same, just don't want to change this initially. Glad you bring this up and I can fix it in this iteration.
Should we still check for this in the SQL codepath ? This limitation really only stemmed from PQL.
removed this.
Why is this even needed ? Ideally, aggregation queries shouldn't even have a LIMIT clause in the Pinot's SQL query.

Right. For aggregation only query, the limit is kind of ignored, unless user really do LIMIT 0.
In our case, limit will be ignored unless specified for aggregation only query.
Is expectedColumnIndices still relevant for testing the SQL end point ?
Yes. I wanna keep this for a while as I haven't changed the query like SELECT  DISTINCT a which is currently using hidden column to rewrite the query.
I see. So am I reading the test on line 103 of this file: "SELECT distinct group_country FROM meetupRsvp  LIMIT 1000000" correctly ? It uses expectedColumnIndices to do this logic ?

I think here is another issue that SELECT distinct group_country FROM meetupRsvp LIMIT 1000000 is not pushed down from recent code.
This is always translated to INSTANCE query SELECT group_country FROM meetupRsvp LIMIT X.
I can address this hidden column in the next PR.

I can think of a few more cases here:

Multiple group by's: "select A, B, Count(1), Sum(C) from Table group by B, A"
Group by's without any aggregations: "select A,  B from Table group by B, A"
will add .
Added.

I didn't follow this: I thought in the SQL end point, its okay to have a Pinot SQL query like: "select count(1), A, B, Sum(C) from Table group by B, A" ... ie the group by columns's don't have to come before the agg columns. (And thus we don't need expectedColumnIndices). Is that case tested ?
I am curious what is the pinot SQL expected for these presto sql queries:

"select A, B, Count(1), Sum(C) from Table group by B, A"
-"select Count(1), A, Sum(C), B from Table group by B, A"

+    }

nodes.bodyText: This one works. Pinot handles the selection expression ordering and return the results following that.

nodes.bodyText:
This method is to override the expected selection clause in the query.
E.g. assume PQL is select Count(1), Sum(C) from Table group by B, A, then in SQL the query will be select B, A, Count(1), Sum(C) from Table group by B, A in order to get same results.

nodes.bodyText: Okay, so this implementation of getExpectedAggOutput does not allow mixing of agg and group by columns. It does handle the group by columns to be explicitly present (which is not the case for PQL). But how would the Presto SQL query with mixed group by and aggregation get translated in the SQL endpoint: "select count(1), A, Sum(C), B from Table group by B, A" ? (note that the aggregations and group by columns are intermingled here and you can't clump the two separately)

nodes.bodyText: The logic is that AggregationNode always have full aggregation/groupby info, and a ProjectNode will handle the assignment. So we can push down another field, say outputColumns, to handle the logic of what to be pushed down in selection.

nodes.bodyText:
Is order by aggregation limit tested ? That's another difference b/w the SQL and the PQL end point. For example, what would be the pinot sql corresponding to this presto sql: "select A, B, Count(1), Sum(C) from Table group by B, A order by SUM(C) ASC limit 3"
Another example: "select A, B, Sum(C) from Table group by B, A order by SUM(C) ASC limit 3"

nodes.bodyText: Why is this an error for this Pinot SQL query ?
This issue is that pinot doesn't support max on a string column. It should be supported soon.

no commented code ;-).
Also, just to confirm: Does this mean that the SQL endpoint has no need for expected column indices because it uses the outputs approach ? Perhaps add a comment to this effect here ?
Added comments.

Does this method really need to modify its state ? Typically the withXXX methods just return a "copy on write" of the existing state. Modifying the selections field here makes me uncomfortable in that it deviates from convention.

Make sense, I move this logic to VisitProject(...)
The logic here is that for SQL mode, selections map contains all the expressions references to row expressions.
commented code

My understanding is that outputs is only used for the SQL code flow, while the PQL codeflow still uses Indices. Can you add a comment here to this effect ? I think we should explain the relationship b/w "selections" and "outputs" better. (For example, is outputs a subset of selections ?)
I also like this outputs way in general -- any sense of what would it take to make the PQL endpoint make use of this new approach too ?

Can you list this line by line like so its easier to read ?
planBuilder
   .aggregation()
   .singleGroupingSet()
I don't see the order by in the plans below.

Can you point me to where the mixed group-by-aggregation projection tests are added ? I couldn't see them in this batch of changes. The closes that it comes to is testAggregationWithGroupByOrderBy. Its important to test those particularly since we switched from expectedColumnIndices to outputs way of handling it.

testAggregationWithGroupBy() has tests for aggregation-groupbys, using AggregationNode and ProjectNode.
testAggregationWithOrderByPushDownInTopN() has tests for aggregation-groupbys-orderbys using AggregationNode and TopNNode.
These have tests with reordering columns.
nit: I think we don't need to retain the historical reference to column indices. Instead should we simply say that the SQL broker page source returns the columns in the order requested by Presto.
I think so. I will update this logic.
done.

I still don't think I am understanding why this is done :-(.
The project node gives us the projections it wants, and we create newSelections (and newOutputs) out of that. So if we use the SQL syntax, why are we retaining what the old selections were ? A comment with some example query/plan when this is needed would certainly help !
If that's the case (that old selections should be retained): Why is not done unconditionally ? Why is it not done by the context ?
In addition, should selections now be a simple HashMap instead of a LinkedHashMap ? There is a new structure outputs to maintain the ordering now.

The reason is newSelections contains the mapping from varRef to rowExpression.
output, groupby, orderby will hold only varRef.
When we try to generate pinot query, the varRef in groupby may not be in output, e.g. select count(*) group by A, in PQL, we expect A is always in selections.
Here in SQL, we need to hold all the mappings somewhere, which is in selections.
Since I somehow don't want to change the logic to generate PQL, I prefer to keep the logic of selection as is

So in theory, can we do this: Make selections be a simple map (not a linked hash map) from varRef to rowExpression. And output is the linked hash set of varRef that says exactly what is actually projected out. And do this for both PQL and SQL endpoints.
ie, in your example above: Both A and count(*) will be in selections, while output will only consist of count(*).  Would that work ?

this works for SQL.
For PQL, we still need to figure out the mapping of expected column indices based on group by conventions (PQL always return groupbys first then aggregations).
nit: outputs -> Outputs, field -> fields
done.
I didn't truly understand why the PQL query generation cannot use outputs and still uses selections.

just my lazy and afraid it may break existing user :)
ok, I will update this logic.
We have pretty good tests for PQL side -- so you shouldn't be able to break it :-)
updated :)
If this test is only for the SQL end point, should it go in TestPinotQueryGeneratorSql ?
will do.
done.

I actually thought that your comment above was very clear to explain the context behind this if condition:
The reason is newSelections contains the mapping from varRef to rowExpression.
output, groupby, orderby will hold only varRef.

When we try to generate pinot query, the varRef in groupby may not be in output, e.g. select count(*) group by A, in PQL, we expect A is always in selections.
Here in SQL, we need to hold all the mappings somewhere, which is in selections.

Can you try to fold some of that comment into the above ? Particularly the example query. It will really bring out the reason more clearly.
Done
Just like line 319 above, should this also be Map<> newSelections = new HashMap<> ? (instead of new LinkedHashMap)

Here the reason is that in our PQL generation test, we create AggregationPlanNode by setting the Aggregations directly, if we use HashMap then generatedPql cannot guarantee the ordering of aggregation functions. Otherwise we need to set a ProjectNode always outside an AggregationPlanNode
Lets please fix the tests instead of complicating the production code like this. Even if it means more changes.
will do :)

The issue is that in visitAggregation method, I didn't explicitly generate outputs, and infer it when calling context.withAggregation by using outputs.addAll(newSelection.keySet()). This is fine when selection is an ordered map.
So the change I made is to generate outputs in visitAggregation method.

I think it would be clearer to rework the condition like: if (!useSqlSyntax && groupByExists && aggregations == 0) ...
It will bring out the intent more clearly that this special casing is only needed in the pql codeflow. In addition you can update the comment on line 476 too to state that.
done.
We can omit the term "order map" above
done.
This line is stale: Outputs are now also used for the PQL code flow -- thank you !!!
done.

Is it possible to dedup these lines with the one below [532-534] ? Particularly line 524 that creates the PinotColumnHandle.
One possible way would be to do this in two steps: In the first step you partition outputs into: groupByColumns and those that are not in groupByColumns and not hidden. Then you can stitch these two partitions and create the column handles in one pass from them. Not sure how much code it would save, but it might help simplify the logic.
composite the pql outputs above the stream() method.
Would this work ?: LinkedHashSet<VariableReferenceExpression> newOutputs = new LinkedHashSet<>(outputColumns);
yes!
This check on line 434 (Cannot find the selection ...) has been dropped. Was it intentional ?
added back.
nit (Everywhere): The convention is to do one argument per line or all arguments on the same line.

nodes.bodyText:
It will make the fields ordering inside OrderBy clause to be not deterministic.
E.g. Presto query SELECT count(*), A, B FROM myTable ORDER BY A,B will make generatedPinot query to be  either SELECT count(*), A, B FROM myTable ORDER BY A,B or  SELECT count(*), A, B FROM myTable ORDER BY B, A.
I somehow feel it's better to keep the ordering as it is in case the underlying connector may take advantage on this(which is not there yet).

                 .add("filter", filter)
                 .add("limit", limit)
                 .add("aggregations", aggregations)
+                .add("useSqlSyntax", useSqlSyntax)
                 .toString();
     }
 
-    PinotQueryGeneratorContext()
+    public PinotQueryGeneratorContext(boolean usePinotSqlSyntax)
     {
-        this(new LinkedHashMap<>(), null);
+        this(new HashMap<>(), new LinkedHashSet<>(), null, usePinotSqlSyntax);

done :)
is it possible we make counter a private data member, and return counter here?

So the problem is that the Broker page source is one shot: It does not have a notion of partial or a cursor: Either the number of completed positions is zero or it is the entire number of rows being returned.
The current usage of completed positions (if you search for the callers of this function), is to basically show a progress indicator while the query is running. That does not fit the broker page source semantics: Because the counter will only change basically when the query is finished (ie when the counter is numRows, then the page source is already done and the query is being torn down)
I think counter is completed positions?
replied above.
could outputs be Set? LinkedHashSet is an implementation
I would very much like to keep it as a LinkedHashSet ... I can't tell you the number of times this has bit me: If order is needed then it should be statically checked.
